item.question: According to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS), in which directory (full path name) should you look for system logfiles?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a file?
item.choice: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
the file will be persistent in memory
the file can only be deleted by the owner or a user with root-privileges.
the file can never be deleted by a regular user
item.correct_answer: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
item.hint: Remember we are talking Linux here.

item.question:
On a Red Hat 5 system, which of the following commands can you use to update the package bind to the latest available version?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are editing a file in vi and are currently in command-modus.
Which of the following vi-commands will move the cursor 5 lines down and 2 characters to the right?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You started an application (myapp) in the foreground.
How do you push this running application into the background without restarting the application?
item.choice: It is not possible without restarting the application.
item.hint: An application running in the foreground is able to receive signals using key combinations through a terminal. An application running in the background is not.

item.question: Which filesystems are mounted using <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> when you issue the command <font face="monospace">mount -a</font>?
item.choice: All filesystems except those on removable media.
None, you forgot to specify a device-file and mount location.
All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.correct_answer: All filesystems except those that have <font face="monospace">noauto</font> specified as mount-option.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to know the previous runlevel your system was running.
Which command can be used to find the previous runlevel?

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command that will not shutdown the system but will send the warning message that the system will shutdown.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed

item.question: What will be the result of the above command?
item.choice: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
Changes to a directory named <font face="monospace">~guru0</font>
Changes to directory named <font face="monospace">guru0</font> in the current directory
item.correct_answer: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory

item.question:
Suppose user pete has created a new application atop, and copied it to the directory /usr/local/bin.
On your system each user belongs to his/her own unique group.
For instance, user petra belongs to the group petra and pete belongs to the group pete.
You would like all the users who do not belong to the group and are not owner of the application to be able to run your application.
Which of the following command lines would allow the appropriate access?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How can you disable only the group quota in <font face="monospace">/extra</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are a regular user (not root) and want to examine the PCI bus configuration.
Which command can you use?
item.choice: None of the mentioned choices, it is only possible with <font face="monospace">root</font>-privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
With the command __________ you can display a file in octal format.
Provide only the name of the command.
item.hint: The question asks for only the commandname so providing the path as well, even if correct, is considered a wrong answer.

item.question:
You installed a new set of shared libraries in /usr/local/mynewlib.
You run the command ldconfig.
However, running the application still causes problems, complaining it cannot find the shared libraries.
What is most likely the cause of this?
item.choice: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
When you install new libraries, you need to recompile or re-install the application.
You forgot to add the library path to the <font face="monospace">PATH</font> variable.
You forgot to reboot the system (the libraries are discovered at kernel initialization).
item.correct_answer: You forgot to enter the library path in <font face="monospace">ld.so.conf</font>.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will print the usage of each mounted filesystem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to update a tar-archive you previously made.
Which option for the command tar best performs the given task?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with test to the directory testing.
Which of the following commands would be best to perform this task?
item.hint: The question states you want to MOVE the directories which means you can eliminate one answer immediately. The question also states you want to move ONLY directories which eliminates another answer. Now you are left with two possible answers and it comes down to knowing if the command requires an option or not.

item.question: Which command line can be used to restart a running Linux system immediately?
item.hint: The question clearly states the system should restart IMMEDIATELY.

item.question:
You started the program rups in the background and you notice it consumes a lot of resources.
Which of the following commands can you use to make the command you just started use less CPU resources?
item.hint: The question is about changing the priority of a RUNNING proces. Changing the priority is done by changing the nice value of the proces. A lower value means less nice, a higher value means the proces is nicer to other processes regarding CPU resources.

item.question:
At the commandline you set a variable's value with the command export MYVAR=hello.
Afterwards you execute the above script.
When the script finishes you type the command echo $MYVAR.
What would be the output of the last command you executed?
item.hint: The script is started by a child proces. Therefore the variable <font face="monospace">MYVAR</font> in the script is set in the child proces and will be lost when the script finishes.

item.question:
You are searching for the file ring which is owned by user frodo.
Assuming the file is on a mounted filesystem and permissions are sufficient,
which command most likely will display its full path name?
item.hint: The question mentions a mounted filesystem and asks you the most likely command that will find the file. This kind of information is essential to answer this question correctly. If this was not added more answers would be correct. Try to remember the difference between find and locate. That should provide you with enough clues to answer the question correctly.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The root filesystem resides on device <font face="monospace">/dev/sda2</font>. What is the corresponding name for this device in GRUB's configuration file at the line '<font face="monospace">root (</font>_______<font face="monospace">)</font>'? (Assume GRUB 1 is used)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which run level can be used as administration mode?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file/directory usually has a sticky bit?
item.choice: Every file that needs to stay memory-resident.
item.hint: When the question mentions something in general you must assume how things are done in Debian or RedHat system or specified in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

item.question: Which of the following commands can you use to create a new file called atcomputing?
item.hint: Although it is not stated explicitly multiple answers may be correct. If there are multiple correct answers you should select all to answer the question correctly.

item.question: If you want to change the default runlevel on a RedHat system to start a graphical login which line would you use in <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You changed the file <font face="monospace">/etc/inittab</font>. What would be your next action to make the change effective?
item.choice: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.correct_answer: Use the command <font face="monospace">kill</font> to send the <font face="monospace">HUP</font> signal
item.hint: Technically multiple answers are correct. However, LPI examinates good system administrator practices. That means minimizing downtime of the services you maintain.

item.question:
You have a text file (hitchhiker.txt) in which you want to replace every 'arthur' by 'Arthur'.
You decide to use sed to make this happen.
What is the correct commandline?
item.hint: The question states you want to replace EVERY arthur with Arthur. Hence, you should do a global replacement. Also note that the file <font face="monospace">hitchhiker.txt</font> should be updated. The question does not mention anything about creating a new file.

item.question: What is the devicefile of the first primary partition on the second SCSI-harddisk?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you create a new directory, you see the permissions are set to rwx--x---.
Which umask value would cause this to happen?
item.hint: When creating a directory the command <font face="monospace">mkdir</font> asks for a certain set of permissions and <font face="monospace">umask</font> is used to determine what the directory will eventually get. In general, the permissions asked when creating a directory are different from when creating a new file.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
You now want to know which echo command was executed.
Which command is best fit for the job?
item.hint: When it is not stated explicitly which shell is used assume the Bash shell.

item.question: Which condition(s) must be true if two directories each require their own quotum for filesystem usage?
item.choice: They must exist on Ext3 partitions
The directories must have the setgid permission set.
They must be on different partitions
They must be mounted by the root user
item.correct_answer: They must be on different partitions

item.question:
You are looking for an executable file foo.
Select TWO commands that would search for foo within directories set in the shell variable $PATH.
item.hint: You are required to provide TWO answers. So select two, no more, no less. The question asks for an executable file, not just any file named <font face="monospace">foo</font>.

item.question: What is the maximum number of primary partitions a single harddisk can contain?
item.hint: If the question requires you to type in the answer and the answer contains a number be sure to type in the number and not as text. For example if your answer is 6 type 6 and NOT six.

item.question:
Which runlevels should you NOT select as default runlevel in /etc/inittab?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about which runlevels are actually used on a Linux system. The question asks which runlevels you should NOT select in order to get a workable running system.

item.question:
Which commands would check the integrity of an ext2 filesystem?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will the command kill -HUP 134 most likely do?
item.choice: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
Give the process a new process number.
item.correct_answer: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
item.hint: As the question does not say what <font face="monospace">134</font> is you need to know what sending the signal <font face="monospace">HUP</font> will do in general.

item.question: Which command can be used to show all shell-variables?
item.hint: The Bash shell treats all variables equal but some are more equal than others. The most equal variables are exported to its children and the others are not. The question is about showing ALL variables, so not only the exported ones.

item.question: What will the above command do?
item.choice: Write the directory listing to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
Write all directories and files to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font> and discard errors
item.correct_answer: Write all directories and files and errors to the file <font face="monospace">contents.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following statements about symbolic links is true?
item.choice: A symbolic link can be recognized by filetype l as being the most-left character in the output of ls -l.
It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
The command <font face="monospace">find / -type s</font> only displays symbolic links.
A symbolic link does not have its own inode-number.
item.correct_answer: It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

You want to use vi-like editing commands at the bash command line editor.
However, the default bash settings enable emacs-like keystrokes.
How do you enable bash to recognize vi-like keystrokes?

item.question: What is the mountpoint of the first swap partition?

item.question:
When partitioning a disk with more than 1024 cylinders, which of the following could affect the systems ability to boot?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The location of the Master Boot Record
Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.correct_answer: Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.hint: This problem occured years ago on systems where the BIOS did not support disks with more then 1024 cylinders. Nowadays you will probably never encounter this problem although Linux is occasionally used on old systems someone has lying around.

item.question: Which command will show you a list of your previously executed commands?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.exhibit:
$ touch nicefile
$ ls -l nicefile
-rw-r--r-- 1 guru0 cursus 0 Sep 28 13:57 nicefile
item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What is the most probable value of the umask set for user guru0?
item.hint: With <font face="monospace">umask</font> you can specify the mask numerically or symbolically. When the mask is in numeric form it specifies what is blocked.
